intro: Geanthus sanguineus, commonly known as the bloodroot, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its distinctive red-orange sap, which gives it its common name. The plant has a short, stout stem with a single, palmate leaf and a cluster of small, white flowers. It typically grows in moist, wooded areas and thrives in partial shade. Botanically, it is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes poppies and other flowering plants with showy blooms.
